intro: Winklera patrinioides, commonly known as the Patrinioides mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant native to the high-altitude forests of South America. It belongs to the family Loranthaceae and typically attaches itself to the branches of host trees such as oaks and pines. The plant lacks true leaves and instead has scale-like structures, relying on its host for water and nutrients while producing its own food through photosynthesis. Its small, white or yellowish flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and it produces small, fleshy berries that are dispersed by birds. Due to its specialized ecological role, it is considered an important component of cloud forest ecosystems.
